instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the batteryâ€™s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

I am working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. Charger was stuck at 5V, after replacing UB400 I'm getting 20V 0,0A on other 3 ports, the port UB400 is responsible for is still stuck at 5V.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.77v. 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.4v.

Can UB400 be responsible for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> not being created properly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: There should be <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> issue; post its basic voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thank you for your time so far.

The voltages I could measure are:

<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.00V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> 0.776V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> 0.776V
<SIGNAL>TBA_BGATE</SIGNAL> 0.2mV
<SIGNAL>TBA_BOOT1</SIGNAL> 4.70V
<SIGNAL>TBA_BOOT2</SIGNAL> 4,74V
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSO_N</SIGNAL> 0.776V
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSO_P</SIGNAL> 0.776V
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q1</SIGNAL> 2.8mV
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q2</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q3</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q4</SIGNAL> 2.8mV
<SIGNAL>TBA_LX1</SIGNAL> 2.8mV
<SIGNAL>TBA_LX2</SIGNAL> 2.8mV

I then accidentally shorted <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7009</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7090</RESISTOR> while measuring.
Now <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing so I think I fried <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

I already ordered a replacement for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and have to wait for it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry to hear that.
Pay more atention when you work on these new boards.

BTW, basic pins are <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>MPM_PBUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>VR1_3P3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi

I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> now.

<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> 20.17V
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>    5.01V
DDA 5.13 V
DDP 5.13V
<SIGNAL>MPM_PBUS</SIGNAL> 19.81V
<SIGNAL>VR1_3P3</SIGNAL>    3.327V
<SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> 5.12V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>* 3.331V
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> 3.331V
AMON 15mV
BMON 2mV

for <SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL> I could not find a probe point on the board view.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still 0.77v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Post again diode mode at F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
0V at F7000

Edit: or do you mean <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground? That is 4.1V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I mean diode mode reading (no charger, nor battery connected); as ALWAYS, red probe at ground!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: yes, I measured diode mode.  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground is 4.1V and diode mode between F7000 pads is 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm wondering how can you get 4.1V in diode mode :eek:.
Did you test with red probe at ground and black probe at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>???
Disconnect charger and battery; allow 10s before diode mode test.

BTW, forget the "V" when you post diode mode reading.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sorry, I meant to write 0.41 and not 4.1. ?   It measures 0.41

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>, 0.77v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Remove F7000 and check voltage at <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR>.
